citations.narrative:
At the time of the inspection, there were 12 dogs over 16 weeks of age that did not have official identification. Inability of a
licensee to readily and correctly identify dogs within the facility could lead to errors in tracing, treatment, or care of the
dogs and could adversely impact the health or well-being of the dogs.
All live dogs on the premises above 16 weeks of age must be identified by one of the following: 1) an official tag of the
type described in 2.51 affixed to the dog’s neck by means of a collar, 2) a tattoo approved by the Administrator, or 3) a
microchip.
To be corrected by close of business on 7/21/2025.

At the time of the inspection, puppy/cage cards used by the licensee as acquisition records for puppies under 16 weeks of
age, born at the facility, did not include the USDA license number of the licensee. Records provide an important source of
information for the identification of animals at the facility and can be important for tracing animals.
The licensee shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the USDA license number
of the person (if he or she is licensed or registered) from whom each dog was purchased or otherwise acquired, owned,
held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control.
To be corrected by close of business on 7/18/2025.

At the time of the inspection, the licensee had not fully implemented the written program of veterinary care (PVC) for dogs
regarding the prescribed preventive treatment for Parvovirus, Distemper virus, Adenovirus, and heartworm. The program
of veterinary care required annual vaccination of adult breeding age dogs for Parvovirus, Distemper virus, and Adenovirus
and the monthly administration of ivermectin to the adult breeding aged dogs. Medical records showed, and the licensee
acknowledged, that 16 adult breeding age dogs had not received a booster vaccination for Parvovirus, Distemper virus,
and Adenovirus in over 12 months. In addition, medical records showed, and the licensee acknowledged, that none of the
adult breeding age dogs had consistently received a monthly dose of ivermectin. Most of the breeding age adult dogs had
only received two doses of ivermectin in the previous 6 months.
Failure to implement the preventative treatments prescribed in the program of veterinary care, by the attending
veterinarian, can lead to the development of diseases in the dogs that cause illness, discomfort, or death.
The licensee must follow the program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented, and signed by the
attending veterinarian. This includes administering the prescribed preventive treatments for contagious and deadly
diseases, parasites, and other pests (such as rabies, parvovirus, distemper, fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and
heartworm, etc.), in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 9/6/2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.50(a)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
At the time of the inspection, there were 12 dogs over 16 weeks of age that did not have official identification. Inability of a 
licensee to readily and correctly identify dogs within the facility could lead to errors in tracing, treatment, or care of the 
dogs and could adversely impact the health or well-being of the dogs. 
 
All live dogs on the premises above 16 weeks of age must be identified by one of the following: 1) an official tag of the 
type described in 2.51 affixed to the dog’s neck by means of a collar, 2) a tattoo approved by the Administrator, or 3) a 
microchip. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on 7/21/2025. 
2.75(a)(1)(ii) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
At the time of the inspection, puppy/cage cards used by the licensee as acquisition records for puppies under 16 weeks of 
age, born at the facility, did not include the USDA license number of the licensee. Records provide an important source of 
information for the identification of animals at the facility and can be important for tracing animals. 
 
The licensee shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the USDA license number 
of the person (if he or she is licensed or registered) from whom each dog was purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, 
held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on 7/18/2025. 
3.13(a)(3)  Repeat
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
At the time of the inspection, the licensee had not fully implemented the written program of veterinary care (PVC) for dogs 
regarding the prescribed preventive treatment for Parvovirus, Distemper virus, Adenovirus, and heartworm. The program 
of veterinary care required annual vaccination of adult breeding age dogs for Parvovirus, Distemper virus, and Adenovirus

and the monthly administration of ivermectin to the adult breeding aged dogs. Medical records showed, and the licensee 
acknowledged, that 16 adult breeding age dogs had not received a booster vaccination for Parvovirus, Distemper virus, 
and Adenovirus in over 12 months. In addition, medical records showed, and the licensee acknowledged, that none of the 
adult breeding age dogs had consistently received a monthly dose of ivermectin. Most of the breeding age adult dogs had 
only received two doses of ivermectin in the previous 6 months. 
 
Failure to implement the preventative treatments prescribed in the program of veterinary care, by the attending 
veterinarian, can lead to the development of diseases in the dogs that cause illness, discomfort, or death. 
 
The licensee must follow the program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented, and signed by the 
attending veterinarian. This includes administering the prescribed preventive treatments for contagious and deadly 
diseases, parasites, and other pests (such as rabies, parvovirus, distemper, fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and 
heartworm, etc.), in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 9/6/2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and 
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
